dt: used to express permission, liberty, probability, or possibility in the past

dt.t: The president {wi}might{/wi} do nothing without the board's consent.

dt: used to say that something is possible

dt.t: We {wi}might{/wi} get there before it rains.
I {wi}might{/wi} go, but then again, I {wi}might{/wi} not.

dt: used to express a present condition contrary to fact

dt.t: If you were older you {wi}might{/wi} understand.

dt: used as a polite alternative to {it}may{/it}

dt.t: {wi}Might{/wi} I ask who is calling?

dt: used as a polite alternative to {it}ought{/it} or {it}should{/it}

dt.t: You {wi}might{/wi} at least apologize.
I {wi}might{/wi} have known she'd be late.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}meahte, mihte{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}mahta, mohta{/it} could
shortdef: —used to express permission, liberty, probability, or possibility in the past
—used to say that something is possible
—used to express a present condition contrary to fact

dt: {bc}the power, authority, or resources wielded (as by an individual or group)
{bc}the power, energy, or intensity of which one is capable

dt.t: ran with all her {wi}might{/wi}
striving with {wi}might{/wi} and main

pt: {sc}power{/sc} {sc}force{/sc} {sc}energy{/sc} {sc}strength{/sc} {sc}might{/sc} mean the ability to exert effort. {sc}power{/sc} may imply latent or exerted physical, mental, or spiritual ability to act or be acted upon.
{sc}force{/sc} implies the actual effective exercise of power.

pt.t: used enough {it}force{/it} to push the door open

pt: {sc}energy{/sc} applies to power expended or capable of being transformed into work.
{sc}strength{/sc} applies to the quality or property of a person or thing that makes possible the exertion of force or the withstanding of strain, pressure, or attack.

pt.t: use weight training to build your {it}strength{/it}

pt: {sc}might{/sc} implies great or overwhelming power or strength.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}miht{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}maht{/it} might, {it}magan{/it} to be able {ma}{mat|may:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: the power, authority, or resources wielded (as by an individual or group)
the power, energy, or intensity of which one is capable

dt: used to indicate possibility or probability

dt.t: you {wi}may{/wi} be right
things you {wi}may{/wi} need
one of those slipups that {wi}may{/wi} happen from time to time

dt: sometimes used where {it}might{/it} would be expected

dt.t: you {wi}may{/wi} think from a little distance that the country was solid woods
you {wi}may{/wi} go now
a rug on which children {wi}may{/wi} sprawl

dt: used in auxiliary function expressing purpose or expectation

dt.t: I laugh that I {wi}may{/wi} not weep
she'll do her duty come what {wi}may{/wi}
he {wi}may{/wi} be slow but he is thorough
the angler {wi}may{/wi} catch them with a dip net, or he {wi}may{/wi} cast a large, bare treble hook

dt: used in auxiliary function to express a wish or desire especially in prayer, imprecation, or benediction

dt.t: {wi}may{/wi} the best man win

dt: used in law where the sense, purpose, or policy requires this interpretation

pt: {it}Can{/it} and {it}may{/it} are most frequently interchangeable in uses denoting possibility; because the possibility of one's doing something may depend on another's acquiescence, they have also become interchangeable in the sense denoting permission. The use of {it}can{/it} to ask or grant permission has been common since the 19th century and is well established, although some commentators feel {it}may{/it} is more appropriate in formal contexts. {it}May{/it} is relatively rare in negative constructions ({it}mayn't{/it} is not common); {it}cannot{/it} and {it}can't{/it} are usual in such contexts.

et: Middle English (1st & 3rd singular present indicative), from Old English {it}mæg{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}mag{/it} (1st & 3rd singular present indicative) have power, am able (infinitive {it}magan{/it}), and perhaps to Greek {it}mēchos{/it} means, expedient
shortdef: —used to indicate possibility or probability —sometimes used interchangeably with can —sometimes used where might would be expected
have permission to : be free to —used nearly interchangeably with can

dt: used to say that people who have power are able to do what they want because no one can stop them

shortdef: —used to say that people who have power are able to do what they want because no one can stop them

dt: used as a response to something that seems unlikely to happen

dt.t: "This time I think he'll ask me to marry him!" "Yeah, and {it}pigs might fly{/it}."

shortdef: —used as a response to something that seems unlikely to happen

dt.t: {it}Try as he might{/it}, he couldn't do it.

shortdef: no matter how hard one tries

dt.t: He swung the bat {it}with all his might{/it}.

dt: used to suggest a possible way of describing or thinking about something

dt.t: The experience was, {it}you might say{/it}, a glimpse into the future.

shortdef: —used to suggest a possible way of describing or thinking about something

dt: used in the phrase {phrase}with might and main{/phrase}

dt.t: The next instant we were away down the river, clawing {wi}with might and main{/wi} to keep out of the woods.
they are in the {wi}main{/wi} well-trained

dt: {bc}a pipe, duct, or circuit which carries the combined flow of tributary branches of a utility system

et: in sense 1, from Middle English, from Old English {it}mǣgen{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}magan{/it} strength, Old English {it}magan{/it} to be able; in other senses, from {et_link|main:2|main:2} or by shortening {ma}{mat|may:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: physical strength : force —used in the phrase with might and main

dt: used to express criticism or disagreement in a polite way

dt.t: The whole affair—{it}if I may say so{/it}—was a waste of time.

shortdef: —used to express criticism or disagreement in a polite way
